Title.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed the impact of behaviour change technique-based interventions

Participants.evidence: patients with intermittent claudication, who are less active than their peers

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either a behaviour change technique-based intervention or standard care as a control.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed the impact of behaviour change technique-based interventions on daily physical activity and clinical outcomes

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in daily physical activity, measured in steps per day, over short-term (<6 months) and maintenance (>6 months) periods.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 allocated to each group, during the recruitment period from January 2020 to June 2021.

Result_Outcome.evidence: In the short term, the intervention group demonstrated a significant increase in daily physical activity (standardised mean difference = 0.20, 95% CI 0.07 to 0.33, ~473 steps/day) compared to the control group.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.

Funding.evidence: FUNDING: National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR) Health Technology Assessment programme (NIHR award ref: NIHR130664).
